--- title: 'AE 05: Wrangling College Majors' subtitle: Suggested answers categories: - Application exercise - Answers execute: warning: false error: false --- ::: callout-important These are suggested answers. This document should be used as reference only, it's not designed to be an exhaustive key. ::: ## Goal Our ultimate goal in this application exercise is to make the following data visualization. ::: {#1e3a0520 .cell execution_count=1} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display} ![](ae-05-majors-tidying-A_files/figure-html/cell-2-output-1.png){width=685 height=538} ::: ::: ## Data For this exercise you will work with data on the proportions of Bachelor’s degrees awarded in the US between 2005 and 2015. The dataset you will use is in your `data/` folder and it’s called `degrees.csv`. ::: {#load-packages-data .cell message='false' execution_count=2} ``` {.python .cell-code} import pandas as pd import matplotlib.pyplot as plt from matplotlib.ticker import FormatStrFormatter import seaborn as sns degrees = pd.read_csv("data/degrees.csv") ``` ::: And let's take a look at the data. ::: {#b47d4f34 .cell execution_count=3} ``` {.python .cell-code} degrees.head() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=3} ```{=html}
field 1971 1976 1981 1986 1991 1996 2001 2005 2006 2007 2008 2009 2010 2011 2012 2013 2014 2015
0 Agriculture and natural resources 12672.0 19402.0 21886.0 16823.0 13124 21425 23370 23002.0 23053.0 23133.0 24113 24982.0 26343.0 28630.0 30972.0 33592.0 35125.0 36277.0
1 Architecture and related services 5570.0 9146.0 9455.0 9119.0 9781 8352 8480 9237.0 9515.0 9717.0 9805 10119.0 10051.0 9831.0 9727.0 9757.0 9149.0 9090.0
2 Area, ethnic, cultural, gender, and group studies 2579.0 3577.0 2887.0 3021.0 4776 5633 6160 7569.0 7879.0 8194.0 8454 8772.0 8620.0 8955.0 9228.0 8850.0 8275.0 7782.0
3 Biological and biomedical sciences 35705.0 54154.0 43078.0 38395.0 39482 61014 60576 65915.0 70607.0 76832.0 79829 82828.0 86391.0 89984.0 95850.0 100397.0 104657.0 109896.0
4 Business 115396.0 143171.0 200521.0 236700.0 249165 226623 263515 311574.0 318042.0 327531.0 335254 348056.0 358119.0 365133.0 367235.0 360887.0 358132.0 363799.0
``` ::: ::: ## Pivoting - **Demo:** Pivot the `degrees` data frame *longer* such that each row represents a degree type / year combination and `year` and `n`umber of graduates for that year are columns in the data frame. ::: {#19bc39e5 .cell execution_count=4} ``` {.python .cell-code} degree = degrees.melt(id_vars='field', var_name='year', value_name='n') degree.info() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` RangeIndex: 594 entries, 0 to 593 Data columns (total 3 columns): # Column Non-Null Count Dtype --- ------ -------------- ----- 0 field 594 non-null object 1 year 594 non-null object 2 n 576 non-null float64 dtypes: float64(1), object(2) memory usage: 14.0+ KB ``` ::: ::: - **Question:** What is the type of the `year` variable? Why? What should it be? It's an `object` variable since the information came from the columns of the original data frame and R cannot know that these character strings represent years. The variable type should be numeric. - **Demo:** Start over with pivoting, and this time also make sure `year` is a numerical variable in the resulting data frame. ::: {#09a235a1 .cell execution_count=5} ``` {.python .cell-code} degree = degrees.melt(id_vars='field', var_name='year', value_name='n') degree['year'] = pd.to_datetime(degree['year'], format='%Y') degree.info() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` RangeIndex: 594 entries, 0 to 593 Data columns (total 3 columns): # Column Non-Null Count Dtype --- ------ -------------- ----- 0 field 594 non-null object 1 year 594 non-null datetime64[ns] 2 n 576 non-null float64 dtypes: datetime64[ns](1), float64(1), object(1) memory usage: 14.0+ KB ``` ::: ::: - **Question:** What does an `NaN` mean in this context? *Hint:* The data come from the university registrar, and they have records on every single graduates, there shouldn't be anything "unknown" to them about who graduated when. `NA`s should actually be 0s. - **Demo:** Add on to your pipeline that you started with pivoting and convert `NaN`s in `n` to `0`s. ::: {#255a05f6 .cell execution_count=6} ``` {.python .cell-code} degree = degrees.melt(id_vars='field', var_name='year', value_name='n') degree['year'] = pd.to_datetime(degree['year'], format='%Y') degree.fillna(0, inplace=True) degree.isna().sum() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=6} ``` field 0 year 0 n 0 dtype: int64 ``` ::: ::: - **Demo:** In our plot the degree types are Business, Computer and information sciences, Engineering, and Psychology. This information is in our dataset, in the `degree` column, but this column also has additional characters we don't need. Filter the dataframe with levels Business, Computer and information sciences, Engineering, and Psychology based on `degree`. Do this by adding on to your pipeline from earlier. ::: {#218c0d42 .cell execution_count=7} ``` {.python .cell-code} degree = degrees.melt(id_vars='field', var_name='year', value_name='n') degree['year'] = pd.to_datetime(degree['year'], format='%Y') degree.fillna(0, inplace=True) selected_fields = degree[(degree['field'].isin(['Business', 'Engineering', 'Computer and information sciences', 'Psychology']))] degree.head() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=7} ```{=html}
field year n
0 Agriculture and natural resources 1971-01-01 12672.0
1 Architecture and related services 1971-01-01 5570.0
2 Area, ethnic, cultural, gender, and group studies 1971-01-01 2579.0
3 Biological and biomedical sciences 1971-01-01 35705.0
4 Business 1971-01-01 115396.0
``` ::: ::: - **Demo:** This does will produce data from 1971 to 2015. Add to the filter with an `&` operator to additionally filter only data from 2005 to 2015. ::: {#1eaacdac .cell execution_count=8} ``` {.python .cell-code} degree = degrees.melt(id_vars='field', var_name='year', value_name='n') degree['year'] = pd.to_datetime(degree['year'], format='%Y') degree.fillna(0, inplace=True) selected_fields = degree[(degree['field'].isin(['Business', 'Engineering', 'Computer and information sciences', 'Psychology'])) & (degree['year'].dt.year >= 2005) & (degree['year'].dt.year <= 2015)] ``` ::: - **Your turn (5 minutes):** Now we start making our plot, but let's not get too fancy right away. Create the following plot, which will serve as the "first draft" on the way to our [Goal]. Do this by adding on to your pipeline from earlier. ::: {#6ce98cc5 .cell execution_count=9} ``` {.python .cell-code} sns.set_style("darkgrid") plt.figure(figsize=(8, 6)) sns.lineplot(data=selected_fields, x='year', y='n', hue='field', marker='o') plt.legend() plt.show() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display} ![](ae-05-majors-tidying-A_files/figure-html/cell-10-output-1.png){width=685 height=501} ::: ::: - **Your turn (4 minutes):** What aspects of the plot need to be updated to go from the draft you created above to the [Goal] plot at the beginning of this application exercise. - line colors - axis labels: title, x, y - theme - **Demo:** Update line colors using the following level / color assignments. Once again, do this by adding on to your pipeline from earlier. - Business: "#53868B" - Engineering: "#7AC5CD" - Computer and information sciences: "#8B814C" - Psychology: "#CDBE70" ::: {#3b620da0 .cell execution_count=10} ``` {.python .cell-code} custom_palette = { "Business": "#53868B", "Engineering": "#7AC5CD", "Computer and information sciences": "#8B814C", "Psychology": "#CDBE70" } plt.figure(figsize=(8, 6)) sns.lineplot(data=selected_fields, x='year', y='n', hue='field', marker='o', palette=custom_palette) plt.show() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display} ![](ae-05-majors-tidying-A_files/figure-html/cell-11-output-1.png){width=685 height=501} ::: ::: - **Your turn:** Update the plot labels (`title`, `x`, and `y`) and use `sns.set_style("white_grid")`. Once again, do this by adding on to your pipeline from earlier. ::: {#fad80167 .cell execution_count=11} ``` {.python .cell-code} sns.set_style("whitegrid") custom_palette = { "Business": "#53868B", "Engineering": "#7AC5CD", "Computer and information sciences": "#8B814C", "Psychology": "#CDBE70" } plt.figure(figsize=(8, 6)) sns.lineplot(data=selected_fields, x='year', y='n', hue='field', marker='o', palette=custom_palette) plt.title('Selected Majors over the years\nAcademic years 2005 - 2015') plt.xlabel('Graduation year') plt.ylabel('Number of majors graduating') plt.legend(title='Degree type') plt.grid(True) plt.show() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display} ![](ae-05-majors-tidying-A_files/figure-html/cell-12-output-1.png){width=685 height=538} ::: :::
